H0.text: Diameter of the planet causes a solar day, which on Jupiter lasts only 9 hours and 50 minutes.

H1.text: The rotational speed of the planet causes a solar day on Jupiter, which lasts only 9 hours and 50 minutes.

H2.text: The speed of a planet in orbit around the sun causes a solar day, which on Jupiter lasts only 9 hours and 50 minutes.

H3.text: The diameter of the orbit of a planet around the sun causes a solar day, as illustrated by Jupiterâ€™s solar day lasting only 9 hours and 50 minutes.

A5.text: The other type of commonly used 'rotation period' is the object's synodic rotation period (or solar day), which may differ, by a fraction of a rotation or more than one rotation, to accommodate the portion of the object's orbital period around a star or another body during one day.

A6.text: For gaseous or fluid bodies, such as stars and giant planets, the period of rotation varies from the object's equator to its pole due to a phenomenon called differential rotation.
